text: I would begin my analysis or approach
from the perspective of power rather
than deliberation or negotiation per se
from there I would ask how deliberation
might be related to the power structure
of the metropolitan area itself a
product of unequal power relations among
different socioeconomic groups Rich from
Rich to poor so would not expect an
alternative dispute resolution process
to be able to do much outside of the
Exton distribution of
power employed by the uh Metropolitan
Authority representing this
configuration of power the mediator's
options would be politically
constrained you must go where they live
so they do the meeting in their places
where they feel a tease and you feel
unease and you feel
embarrassed because you can stand
feeling embarrassed well they cannot if
they come in an office everything is
very strange the power is all in your
hands so you must that is the first step
it is very simple but it is not done
usually so the civil servants and people
who work in the public administration
must learn that they can do
meetings in those neighborhood those
places where these people live and drink
coffee with them and be their
guests because that starts to create
possibility of
trust so this is the first thing which
is very important it would change
completely the way the public
administration
works I think think that the right here
is extremely important the fair share
law creates the right that creates a
conflict or the occasion for
deliberation otherwise without that
right you just have Injustice without
conflict and no occasion for
deliberation so I think the easiest
thing you can do to equalize things is
strengthen the ability of these people
to sue Suburban governments
